content.question: Let <math alttext="f" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> be a differentiable function with <math alttext="f of 0, equals, negative 4 " display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>0</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>4</mn></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="f of 10, equals 11 " display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>10</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mn>11</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. Which of the following must be true for some <math alttext="c" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>c</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> in the interval <math alttext="open parenthesis, 0 comma 10, close parenthesis " display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>0</mn><mo>,</mo><mrow><mn>10</mn></mrow><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> ?

choices.label: <math alttext="f prime of c, equals 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>c</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, since the Extreme Value Theorem applies.

<math alttext="f prime of c, equals, the fraction with numerator 11 plus negative 4, and denominator 10 minus 0, end fraction" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>c</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mn>11</mn><mo>+</mo><mrow><mo>(</mo><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>4</mn></mrow><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow><mrow><mn>10</mn><mo>−</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mstyle></math>, since the Mean Value Theorem applies.

<math alttext="f prime of c, equals, the fraction with numerator 11 minus negative 4, and denominator 10 minus 0, end fraction" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>c</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mn>11</mn><mo>−</mo><mrow><mo>(</mo><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>4</mn></mrow><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow><mrow><mn>10</mn><mo>−</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mstyle></math>, since the Mean Value Theorem applies.

<math alttext="f prime of c, equals, 1.5" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>c</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mn>1.5</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, since the Intermediate Value Theorem applies.

content.answer: <math alttext="f prime of c, equals, the fraction with numerator 11 minus negative 4, and denominator 10 minus 0, end fraction" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>c</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mn>11</mn><mo>−</mo><mrow><mo>(</mo><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>4</mn></mrow><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow><mrow><mn>10</mn><mo>−</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mstyle></math>, since the Mean Value Theorem applies.

skill.text: Skill 3.E: Provide reasons or rationales for solutions and conclusions.
